messageBody:
This is a good argument for not using System.out.println(..) statements in
the code. If you don't want to use a full blown tracing/logging package
(e.g. from qcijutils.qlue.com or the logging package in the upcoming JDK
1.4), you can just define your own static PrintWriter that you can
replace/redirect at will. You can direct that PrintWriter at a particular
file in the setUp() of your testcase.

For example, this is what I do for my projects which use the above
mentioned logging package:

/***********************************************************************
* LoggerTestCase
* QCI Inventory - Database Layer for inventory manipulation
* Author: Eric Vought
* $Id$
*
* A Test Case that supplies a Logger to the class under test.
***********************************************************************/

package com.qlue.apps.inventory.dblayer;

// JUnit
import junit.framework.TestCase;
import junit.framework.TestSuite;
import junit.framework.TestResult;

// Logging
import com.qlue.util.logging.Logger;
import com.qlue.util.logging.LogMask;
import com.qlue.util.logging.WriterLogListener;
import com.qlue.util.logging.LogListener;

// IO
import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileWriter;
import java.io.PrintWriter;

/**
* A Test Case that supplies a Logger to the class under test.
*/
public class LoggerTestCase extends TestCase
{
protected Logger d_logger = null;

public LoggerTestCase(String name)
{
super(name);
} // LoggerTestCase(String)

public void setUp() throws Exception
{
d_logger = setUpLogger();
} // setUp()

public void tearDown() throws Exception
{
tearDownLogger();
} // tearDown()

public Logger setUpLogger() throws Exception
{
Logger logger = new Logger();

File rundir = new File(System.getProperty("test.rundir"));
assert(rundir.exists());

File logFile = new File( rundir,
this.getClass().getName() + "_" + name() + ".log" );

PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter(new FileWriter(logFile));
writer.println("<?xml version=\"1.0\" ?>");
writer.println("<log>");

LogListener listener = new WriterLogListener(
LogMask.logUpTo(LogMask.DEBUG),
writer, null );
listener.open();
logger.addLogListener(listener);


return logger;
} // setUpLogger()

public void tearDownLogger()
{

} // tearDownLogger()

} // class LoggerTestCase

All the testcases which need a logger (or a PrintWriter, in your case),
inherit from LoggerTestCase. Each one ends up in the test output directory
named by test class and test name. ANT cleans up the output directory
before the run and passes in the path to the output directory as a system
property. This gives you a well organized way to collect your trace output
with very little effort.
